author: Abc Rural
title: Dairy farmers doing it tough as milk production hits 21-year low - ABC Rural - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Shepparton 3630 
Despite droughts, floods, deregulation and a global financial crisis in recent memory, the dairy industry has never had it as tough as this financial year. 
According to Dairy Australia's Situation and Outlook report, released today, farmers are likely to produce 700 million fewer litres of milk this year than last year, marking the lowest production in 21 years. 
Not since 1995-1996 have Australian dairy farmers produced fewer than 9 billion litres of milk. 
It is predicted this financial year the Australian industry will produce 8.8 billion litres. 
Low world markets, a sudden and retrospective price drop by major processors Fonterra and Murray Goulburn , and tough, wet weather conditions in winter are all to blame for the significant drop in production. Victoria hit hard by crisis Dairy companies forecasted a milk exporting bonanza. But as the industry soured, many failed to deliver their promises. 
Dairy Australia senior analyst John Droppert said the key dairy region of northern Victoria had borne the brunt of the dairy crisis. 
"They're down around 18 per cent in total volume terms, which is a pretty big volume of milk," he said. 
The drop in milk production also makes it difficult for milk processors to keep an adequate throughput of raw milk into their factories. 
"Less milk inevitably means there is less product available to capitalise on a rising market," Mr Droppert said. 
"That's a problem for processors and ultimately it's a problem for farmers." 
Mr Droppert believes the tension over milk supply makes processors compete harder in the price they pay farmers for milk. External Link: Dairy milk production graph Consumers drinking more milk 
But some numbers are rising â€” while the nation's dairy farmers are producing less, Australians are drinking more milk. 
In response to the dairy crisis, Australians have started to buy more dairy. 
Total milk sales grew in Australia by 2.4 per cent over the 12 months to January. 
Mr Droppert said Australians were turning to full cream milk over lower fat varieties. 
"We've seen a big shift, in the region of 9 per cent growth to full cream milk," he said. 
"You've got to remember this is a mature category so growing at 9 per cent is a pretty significant shift." Strong growth in branded products 
Australians' taste for branded dairy products has also continued since the dairy crisis began in April. 
At that time Australians largely stopped buying private label $1 per litre supermarket milk and turned to branded products. 
Branded product sales suddenly grew from a record low market share of 34 per cent to more than 48 per cent of the market. 
Mr Droppert said the trend had continued, but was not as strong. 
"It's sitting at around 43 per cent at the moment, so it has held on to most of its gains," he said.
